title: 1, 2 Step
text:
"1, 2 Step" is a song by American singer <a href="Ciara">Ciara</a> featuring hip-hop rapper <a href="Missy%20Elliott">Missy Elliott</a> for Ciara's debut album, "<a href="Goodies%20%28Ciara%20album%29">Goodies</a>". Written by Ciara and Missy Elliott and produced by Jazze Pha, it was released as the album's second single on November 1, 2004, in the United States. It peaked within the top 10 of the charts in several countries worldwide, including Germany, New Zealand and the United Kingdom. The song is heavily inspired by 1980s <a href="electro%20music">electro music</a> production. Throughout the song, Ciara gives a description of how the song's <a href="beat%20%28music%29">beat</a> feels as she exhorts party-goers to dance to the music. "1, 2 Step" was ranked 59th on "<a href="Billboard%20%28magazine%29">Billboard</a>"'s Top 100 Songs of the 2000s. In the United States, the song peaked at number two on the "Billboard" Hot 100 and stayed there for seven weeks.
Background and composition.
"1, 2 Step" is one of four songs Ciara and Jazze Pha originally recorded at <a href="Doppler%20Studios">Doppler Studios</a> in <a href="Atlanta">Atlanta</a> two years before the release of "Goodies". It is explained that Ciara was inspired by Roscoe Blunt, leading to the creation of this song. "The two connected so well, that half of the album was made within eight days or so." Pha asked Missy Elliott to appear on the track and she accepted. Elliott recorded her rap verse at the <a href="Criteria%20Studios">Hit Factory Criteria</a> in Miami.
"1, 2 Step" is a Crunk&B track, which is strongly influenced by 1980s electro music. The song was created on one of Jazze Pha's five Akai MPC3000s. Pha used laser pulses from E-mu Proteus in the 2000s that were used for <a href="old%20school%20hip%20hop">old school hip hop</a> songs and <a href="b-boy">b-boy</a> <a href="break%20dance">break dance</a> tracks. "1, 2 Step" is inspired by <a href="Afrika%20Bambaataa">Afrika Bambaataa</a>'s "<a href="Planet%20Rock%20%28song%29">Planet Rock</a>." Jazze Pha thought about how he could create a more melodic version and "shared some interesting ideas on what kind of music he would like to produce with her. Let's put it this way, it would be epic." "1, 2 Step" references her past song "<a href="Goodies%20%28song%29">Goodies</a>" and "<a href="We%20Will%20Rock%20You">We Will Rock You</a>" by <a href="Queen%20%28band%29">Queen</a>. Missy Elliott's verse was inspired by <a href="Teena%20Marie">Teena Marie</a>'s song "<a href="Square%20Biz">Square Biz</a>".
Critical reception.
"1, 2 Step" received favorable reviews from music critics. "<a href="Contact%20Music">Contact Music</a>" gave the song three out of five stars and called it "arse shaking floor filling R&B" and a "wicked melodic souful twist." Jason Birchmeier of "<a href="Allmusic">Allmusic</a>" was published that the track is "good, if not great." Gerardo E. wrote it's "a feel good track," something that is not overproduced but works its magic." Kate Watkins of "The Situation" called it "a funky song in the style we have come to expect from Missy." "Fazed" stated that the song is about "joys of dancing around with family." "<a href="Slant%20%28magazine%29">Slant</a>" thought that "1, 2 Step" was a "fun dance track."
"1, 2 Step" was nominated for the <a href="48th%20Annual%20Grammy%20Awards">2006 Grammy Award</a> for "<a href="Grammy%20Award%20for%20Best%20Rap/Sung%20Collaboration">Best Rap/Sung Collaboration</a>," but lost to "<a href="Numb/Encore">Numb/Encore</a>" by <a href="Jay-Z">Jay-Z</a> and <a href="Linkin%20Park">Linkin Park</a>. The song also received a nomination at the Soul Train Lady of Soul Music Awards for "Best Dance Cut." The song was nominated for "Viewer's Choice" at the 2005 <a href="BET%20Awards">BET Awards</a>, but lost to <a href="Omarion">Omarion</a>'s "<a href="O%20%28Omarion%20song%29">O</a>." The song won the award "Best Performed Songs in the <a href="American%20Society%20of%20Composers%2C%20Authors%20and%20Publishers">ASCAP</a> Repertory for the 2005 Survey Year," which included <a href="Goodies%20%28song%29">the title track</a> from the album as well as third single, "<a href="Oh%20%28Ciara%20song%29">Oh</a>." The song won the award for "Choice Music R&B/Hip Hop Track" at the 2005 <a href="Teen%20Choice%20Awards">Teen Choice Awards</a> and "Best Collaboration" and "Viewer's Choice" at the <a href="BET%20Awards">BET Awards</a> in 2005.
Chart performance.
"1, 2 Step" debuted at number 74 on the <a href="Billboard%20Hot%20100">"Billboard" Hot 100</a>. In the January 8, 2005, issue of "<a href="Billboard%20%28magazine%29">Billboard</a>", the song climbed to number two on the chart and stayed there for seven weeks, while being held from the top slot by Mario's "<a href="Let%20Me%20Love%20You%20%28Mario%20song%29">Let Me Love You</a>" and became Ciara's second top-10 single. "1, 2 Step" reached number one on the "Billboard" <a href="Pop%20100">Pop 100</a> (the first on the then new chart), <a href="Hot%20Dance%20Airplay">Hot Dance Airplay</a>, <a href="Hot%20Digital%20Tracks">Hot Digital Tracks</a>, and <a href="Top%2040%20Mainstream">Top 40 Mainstream</a> charts. It also peaked in the top five on the <a href="Hot%20Digital%20Songs">Hot Digital Songs</a>, <a href="Hot%20R%26amp%3BB/Hip-Hop%20Songs">Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs</a>, <a href="Rhythmic%20Airplay">Rhythmic Airplay</a> and the <a href="Top%2040%20Tracks">Top 40 Tracks</a> charts, and the top 30 on the <a href="Hot%20Dance%20Club%20Play">Hot Dance Club Play</a> chart. "1, 2 Step" was ranked at number five for the year on the <a href="Billboard%20Year-End%20Hot%20100%20singles%20of%202005">Billboard Year-End Hot 100 singles of 2005</a>. The single was certified <a href="RIAA%20Certification">triple platinum</a> by the <a href="Recording%20Industry%20Association%20of%20America">Recording Industry Association of America</a> (RIAA) for sales of over three million digital copies in the United States.
Internationally, "1, 2 Step" was successful, reaching the top 10 in several countries. In the UK and Ireland, "1, 2 Step" entered and peaked at number three on both the <a href="UK%20Singles%20Chart">UK Singles Chart</a> and <a href="Irish%20Singles%20Chart">Irish Singles Chart</a> respectively. In Ireland, the single stayed at three for three weeks. The song reached number two in Australia for one week and New Zealand for two weeks. It peaked at number five in China and was a top 30 hit in Belgium, France, the Netherlands and Sweden.
Music video.
The music video for "1, 2 Step" was directed by <a href="Benny%20Boom">Benny Boom</a>. It takes place in an Atlanta dance studio and on the streets. <a href="Contemporary%20R%26amp%3BB">R&B</a> boy band, <a href="B5%20%28band%29">B5</a>, makes a short appearance in the video, along with <a href="Lloyd%20%28singer%29">Lloyd</a> and <a href="Lil%20Scrappy">Lil Scrappy</a>. Ciara can be seen teaching others the song's title "one, two step" dance, which is similar to the traditional <a href="grapevine%20%28dance%20move%29">grapevine</a>.
Synopsis.
The video begins with Ciara putting her "Goodies" CD in a radio, setting it to the "1, 2 Step" track, and pressing the play button. As the song begins, you see Jazze Pha reciting the introduction, featuring Elliott, and then finally Ciara herself. We see Ciara and her dancers, dancing in the Atlanta dance studio, and certain shots of her teaching her female friend the "1, 2 Step". We then see a clip of Ciara meeting up with B5 and performing the "1, 2 Step". Later, Ciara is seen dancing alone on the streets. While dancing at the studio, she looks behind her, and sees Elliott in the mirror, says she is just looking things. Then Elliott begins to rap her verse and they continue dancing with each other in front of the mirror, until the songs ends. During this time, we also see shots of Ciara teaching a group of young girls the dance and also, she meets a boy who is standing in front of his house and kind of gives him a flirtatious look. We also see four skaters, three male, and one female skater, skating in the streets and a last shot of Ciara and her dancers.
